title: Contributing to serofoi
text: want make change, â€™s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees â€™s needed. â€™ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See bug report template. feature request see feature request.

title: Contributing to serofoi
text: See pull request template Fork package clone onto computer. havenâ€™t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("epiverse-trace/serofoi", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesnâ€™t pass cleanly, â€™s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e.Â just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to serofoi
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please donâ€™t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Simulated data
text: constant endemic model, rate infection acquisitionâ€•rate seroconversionâ€•constant time, infection (sero)prevalence increase monotonically age cumulative exposure increases. Denoting \(n(,t)\) number seropositive individuals age \(\) time \(t\) , \(N\) serosurvey sample size, \(P(,t)\) underlying seroprevalence age \(\) time \(t\), assumed number seropositive subjects follows Binomial distribution \(n(,t)\) ~ \(B(N,P(,t))\). force--infection (FoI) constant time, denoted \(\lambda\), modelled seroprevalence age \(\) year \(t\) (.e.Â time serosurvey occurred) : \[ P(,t) = 1âˆ’exp(âˆ’\lambda{})\] corresponding code constant-FoI model binomial distribution :

title: Simulated data
text: Models implemented RStan using -U-Turn sampler, type Hamiltonian Monte Carlo sampling. convergence, best-fitting models can selected based expected log predictive density --sample data point (elpd).

title: Simulated data
text: Based data analysis shown (CucunubÃ¡ et al. 2017), use one datasets measuring sero-prevalence IgG antibodies Trypanosoma cruzi infection rural area Colombia 2012. dataset part serofoi package chagas2012. preparing data can run two models (constant time varying) available serofoi. Now, can plot results two models compare (Figure 1). shown CucunubÃ¡ et al. (2017), interventions Chagas control ongoing 1980s Colombia heterogeneous impact depending type population. serosurvey, tradittional indigenous rural area, serofoi models able detect modest still relevant slow decreasing trend consistent (model 2) slightly better supported constant model. Notice model 3 converge despite high number iterations.
code: data("chagas2012") head(chagas2012, 5) #>       survey total counts age_min age_max year_init year_end tsur country  test #> 1 COL-035-93    34      0       1       1      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 2 COL-035-93    25      0       2       2      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 3 COL-035-93    35      1       3       3      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 4 COL-035-93    29      0       4       4      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 5 COL-035-93    36      0       5       5      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #>           antibody #> 1 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 2 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 3 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 4 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 5 IgG anti-T.cruzi chagas2012p <- prepare_serodata(chagas2012)  m1_cha <- run_seromodel(serodata = chagas2012p,                              seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",                              n_iters = 500,                               n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model constant_foi_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]               #> seromodel_name "constant_foi_bi"  #> dataset        "COL-035-93"       #> country        "COL"              #> year           "2012"             #> test           "ELISA"            #> antibody       "IgG anti-T.cruzi" #> n_sample       "747"              #> n_agec         "72"               #> n_iter         "500"              #> elpd           "-92.66"           #> se             "6.54"             #> converged      "Yes"  m2_cha <- run_seromodel(serodata = chagas2012p,                              seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_bi",                              n_iters = 1500,                               n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]                       #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_bi" #> dataset        "COL-035-93"               #> country        "COL"                      #> year           "2012"                     #> test           "ELISA"                    #> antibody       "IgG anti-T.cruzi"         #> n_sample       "747"                      #> n_agec         "72"                       #> n_iter         "1500"                     #> elpd           "-74.7"                    #> se             "5.83"                     #> converged      "Yes" p1_cha <- plot_seromodel(m1_cha, size_text = 12, max_lambda = 0.02) p2_cha <- plot_seromodel(m2_cha, size_text = 12, max_lambda = 0.02)  cowplot::plot_grid(p1_cha, p2_cha, nrow = 1, ncol = 2)

what: Case study 2. Hidden Alphaviruses epidemics in Panama
title: Simulated data
text: shown (Carrera et al. 2020), hidden epidemic endemic transmission alphaviruses Eastern Panama around decades. paper use dataset measuring IgG antibodies againts Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis Virus (VEEV) rural village PanamÃ¡ 2017. dataset, veev2017 included serofoi. Now, can plot results three models compare. Figure 3, can observe large increase estimated FOI. suggested Carrera et al. (2020), important increase transmission VEEV region inferred. Although three fitted models converge well, see much larger support sudden increase recent years highest FoI values 0.25 (consistent epidemic).  Figure 3. Results fitted models, Force--Infection estimates convergence.
code: data("veev2012") head(veev2012, 5) #>          survey total counts age_min age_max year_init year_end tsur country #> 1 PAN-2012-VEEV     6      3       1       5      2012     2012 2012     PAN #> 2 PAN-2012-VEEV    14     11       5      10      2012     2012 2012     PAN #> 3 PAN-2012-VEEV    14     11      10      15      2012     2012 2012     PAN #> 4 PAN-2012-VEEV     8      5      15      20      2012     2012 2012     PAN #> 5 PAN-2012-VEEV     8      7      20      25      2012     2012 2012     PAN #>    test      antibody #> 1 ELISA IgG anti-VEEV #> 2 ELISA IgG anti-VEEV #> 3 ELISA IgG anti-VEEV #> 4 ELISA IgG anti-VEEV #> 5 ELISA IgG anti-VEEV veev2012p <- prepare_serodata(veev2012)  m1_veev <- run_seromodel(serodata = veev2012p,                               seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",                               n_iters = 500,                                n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model constant_foi_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]              #> seromodel_name "constant_foi_bi" #> dataset        "PAN-2012-VEEV"   #> country        "PAN"             #> year           "2012"            #> test           "ELISA"           #> antibody       "IgG anti-VEEV"   #> n_sample       "146"             #> n_agec         "17"              #> n_iter         "500"             #> elpd           "-43.81"          #> se             "13.9"            #> converged      "Yes"  m2_veev <- run_seromodel(serodata = veev2012p,                               seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_bi",                               n_iters = 500,                                n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]                       #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_bi" #> dataset        "PAN-2012-VEEV"            #> country        "PAN"                      #> year           "2012"                     #> test           "ELISA"                    #> antibody       "IgG anti-VEEV"            #> n_sample       "146"                      #> n_agec         "17"                       #> n_iter         "500"                      #> elpd           "-28.74"                   #> se             "7.04"                     #> converged      "Yes"  m3_veev <- run_seromodel(serodata = veev2012p,                               seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_log",                               n_iters = 500,                                n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_log finished running ------" #>                [,1]                        #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_log" #> dataset        "PAN-2012-VEEV"             #> country        "PAN"                       #> year           "2012"                      #> test           "ELISA"                     #> antibody       "IgG anti-VEEV"             #> n_sample       "146"                       #> n_agec         "17"                        #> n_iter         "500"                       #> elpd           "-22"                       #> se             "2.99"                      #> converged      "Yes" p1_veev <- plot_seromodel(m1_veev, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.6) p2_veev <- plot_seromodel(m2_veev, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.6) p3_veev <- plot_seromodel(m3_veev, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.6)  cowplot::plot_grid(p1_veev, p2_veev, p3_veev, nrow = 1, ncol = 3)

what: Case study 3. A known Large Chikungunya epidemic in Brazil
title: Simulated data
text: Chikungunya outbreaks ocurred rapidly introduction virus Brazil 2013-2014. use dataset (Dias et al. 2018) conducts population-based study household interviews serologic surveys (measuring IgG antibodies Chikungunya virus) Bahia, Brazil October-December 2015, right large CHIKV epidemic occurred area. Figure 4, can observe comparison three serofoi models. serofoi shows strong statistical support sudden increase transmission CHIKV close year serosurvey (2015). exact year possible estimate, mainly given data used largely aggregated 20-years age groups. Despite , results consistent empirical evidence shown (Dias et al. 2018) interviews, IgM testing.
code: data("chik2015") head(chik2015, 5) #>           survey total counts age_min age_max year_init year_end tsur country #> 1 BRA 2015(S019)   144     63      40      59      2015     2015 2015     BRA #> 2 BRA 2015(S019)   148     69      60      79      2015     2015 2015     BRA #> 3 BRA 2015(S019)    45     17       1      19      2015     2015 2015     BRA #> 4 BRA 2015(S019)   109     55      20      39      2015     2015 2015     BRA #>    test       antibody        reference #> 1 ELISA IgG anti-CHIKV Dias et al. 2018 #> 2 ELISA IgG anti-CHIKV Dias et al. 2018 #> 3 ELISA IgG anti-CHIKV Dias et al. 2018 #> 4 ELISA IgG anti-CHIKV Dias et al. 2018 chik2015p <- prepare_serodata(chik2015)  mod1_chik <- run_seromodel(serodata = chik2015p,                                 seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",                                 n_iters = 1000,                                  n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model constant_foi_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]              #> seromodel_name "constant_foi_bi" #> dataset        "BRA 2015(S019)"  #> country        "BRA"             #> year           "2015"            #> test           "ELISA"           #> antibody       "IgG anti-CHIKV"  #> n_sample       "446"             #> n_agec         "4"               #> n_iter         "1000"            #> elpd           "-39.57"          #> se             "8.48"            #> converged      "Yes"  mod2_chik <- run_seromodel(serodata = chik2015p,                                 seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_bi",                                 n_iters = 1500,                                  n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_bi finished running ------" #>                [,1]                       #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_bi" #> dataset        "BRA 2015(S019)"           #> country        "BRA"                      #> year           "2015"                     #> test           "ELISA"                    #> antibody       "IgG anti-CHIKV"           #> n_sample       "446"                      #> n_agec         "4"                        #> n_iter         "1500"                     #> elpd           "-20.76"                   #> se             "1.98"                     #> converged      "Yes"  mod3_chik <- run_seromodel(serodata = chik2015p,                      seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_log",                      n_iters = 1500,                       n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_log finished running ------" #>                [,1]                        #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_log" #> dataset        "BRA 2015(S019)"            #> country        "BRA"                       #> year           "2015"                      #> test           "ELISA"                     #> antibody       "IgG anti-CHIKV"            #> n_sample       "446"                       #> n_agec         "4"                         #> n_iter         "1500"                      #> elpd           "-12.58"                    #> se             "0.81"                      #> converged      "Yes" p1_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod1_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08) p2_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod2_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08) p3_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod3_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08)  cowplot::plot_grid(p1_chik, p2_chik, p3_chik, nrow = 1, ncol = 3)

1500,                       n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_log finished running ------" #>                [,1]                        #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_log" #> dataset        "BRA 2015(S019)"            #> country        "BRA"                       #> year           "2015"                      #> test           "ELISA"                     #> antibody       "IgG anti-CHIKV"            #> n_sample       "446"                       #> n_agec         "4"                         #> n_iter         "1500"                      #> elpd           "-12.58"                    #> se             "0.81"                      #> converged      "Yes" p1_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod1_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08) p2_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod2_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08) p3_chik <- plot_seromodel(mod3_chik, size_text = 10, max_lambda = 0.08)  cowplot::plot_grid(p1_chik, p2_chik, p3_chik, nrow = 1, ncol = what: serofoi: force-of-infection from population based serosurveys with age-disagregated data
title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: serofoi R package estimates Force--Infection given pathogen age-disaggregated population based sero-prevalence studies, using Bayesian framework. serofoi implements methods outlined (CucunubÃ¡ et al. 2017) (Carrera et al.Â 2020) serofoi relies rstan serofoi part Epiverse Initiative.

title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: can install development version serofoi GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") # remotes::install_github("TRACE-LAC/serofoi") library(serofoi)

title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: package provides example dataset observed serosurvey data, serodata. example basic entry package. function prepare_serodata prepare entry data entering modelling functions. seroprevalence prepared data can visualised plot_seroprev function. function also plots binomial confidence interval observed data.
code: # Load example serodata data included with the package data(serodata) head(serodata, 5) #>       survey total counts age_min age_max year_init year_end tsur country  test #> 1 COL-035-93    34      0       1       1      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 2 COL-035-93    25      0       2       2      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 3 COL-035-93    35      1       3       3      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 4 COL-035-93    29      0       4       4      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #> 5 COL-035-93    36      0       5       5      2012     2012 2012     COL ELISA #>           antibody #> 1 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 2 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 3 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 4 IgG anti-T.cruzi #> 5 IgG anti-T.cruzi data_test <- prepare_serodata(serodata)  plot_seroprev(data_test, size_text = 15)

what: Current version of the package runs three different FoI models
title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: run_seromodel function allows specifying Bayesian model R, running back rstan. number iterations, thinning, parameters can customised. NOTE: Running serofoi models first time local computer make take minutes rstan code compiled locally. Afterwards, local compilation needed.

title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: endemic model small number iterations enough achieving convergence, fits one parameter (constant FoI) binomial distribution.
code: model_1 <- run_seromodel(serodata = data_test,                      seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",                      n_iters = 500,                       n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model constant_foi_bi finished running ------" #>                     [,1]               #> seromodel_name "constant_foi_bi"  #> dataset             "COL-035-93"       #> country             "COL"              #> year                "2012"             #> test                "ELISA"            #> antibody            "IgG anti-T.cruzi" #> n_sample            "747"              #> n_agec              "72"               #> n_iter              "500"              #> elpd                "-92.88"           #> se                  "6.44"             #> converged           "Yes"

title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: epidemic model, larger number iterations required achieving convergence, fits yearly FoI values binomial distribution. number iterations required may depend number years, reflected difference year serosurvey maximum age-class sampled.
code: model_2 <- run_seromodel(serodata = data_test,                      seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_bi",                      n_iters = 1500,                       n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_bi finished running ------" #>                     [,1]                       #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_bi" #> dataset             "COL-035-93"               #> country             "COL"                      #> year                "2012"                     #> test                "ELISA"                    #> antibody            "IgG anti-T.cruzi"         #> n_sample            "747"                      #> n_agec              "72"                       #> n_iter              "1500"                     #> elpd                "-74.69"                   #> se                  "5.83"                     #> converged           "Yes"

title: Estimates the Force-of-Infection of a given pathogen from population based sero-prevalence studies
text: fast epidemic model, larger number iterations required achieving convergence, compared previous models. model, plot_seroprev_model function generate vertical arrange plots summarising results model implementation plotting functions. Crucially, shows (expected) log-predictive density elpd, standard error se, allows check convergence based R-hat convergence diagnostics. Also, means function cowplot::plot_grid comparison models based (expected) log-predictive density elpd, standard error se, allows check convergence based R-hat convergence diagnostics can visualized. detailed information examples, please check online documentation package vignettes Get Started.
code: model_3 <- run_seromodel(serodata = data_test,                      seromodel_name = "continuous_foi_normal_log",                      n_iters = 1500,                       n_thin = 2) #> [1] "serofoi model continuous_foi_normal_log finished running ------" #>                     [,1]                        #> seromodel_name "continuous_foi_normal_log" #> dataset             "COL-035-93"                #> country             "COL"                       #> year                "2012"                      #> test                "ELISA"                     #> antibody            "IgG anti-T.cruzi"          #> n_sample            "747"                       #> n_agec              "72"                        #> n_iter              "1500"                      #> elpd                "-72.22"                    #> se                  "7.15"                      #> converged           "Yes"

title: Function that fits the selected model to the specified seroprevalence survey data. â€” fit_seromodel
text: serodata data frame containing data seroprevalence survey. details refer run_seromodel. seromodel_name Name selected model. Current version provides three options: "constant_foi_bi" Runs constant model "continuous_foi_normal_bi" Runs normal model "continuous_foi_normal_log" Runs normal logarithmic model n_iters Number interations eah chain including warmup. iter sampling. n_thin Positive integer specifying period saving samples. thin sampling. delta Real number 0 1 represents target average acceptance probability. Increasing value delta result smaller step size fewer divergences. details refer control parameter sampling . m_treed Maximum tree depth binary tree used NUTS stan sampler. details refer control parameter sampling. decades Number decades covered survey data.

title: Function that fits the selected model to the specified seroprevalence survey data. â€” fit_seromodel

title: Function that generates a Force-of-Infection plot corresponding to the specified fitted serological model. â€” plot_foi
code: if (FALSE) {    data_test <- prepare_serodata(serodata)    seromodel_object <- run_seromodel(    serodata = data_test,    seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",    n_iters = 1000 ) plot_foi(seromodel_object, size_text = 15) }

what: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
title: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
text: function runs specified model Force--Infection seromodel_name using data froma seroprevalence survey  serodata input data. See fit_seromodel details.

title: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
code: run_seromodel(   serodata,   seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi",   n_iters = 1000,   n_thin = 2,   delta = 0.9,   m_treed = 10,   decades = 0,   print_summary = TRUE )

title: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
text: serodata data frame containing data seroprevalence survey. data frame must contain following columns: last six colums can added serodata means function prepare_serodata. seromodel_name Name selected model. Current version provides three options: "constant_foi_bi" Runs constant model "continuous_foi_normal_bi" Runs normal model "continuous_foi_normal_log" Runs normal logarithmic model n_iters Number interations eah chain including warmup. iter sampling. n_thin Positive integer specifying period saving samples. thin sampling. delta Real number 0 1 represents target average acceptance probability. Increasing value delta result smaller step size fewer divergences. details refer control parameter sampling . m_treed Maximum tree depth binary tree used NUTS stan sampler. details refer control parameter sampling. decades Number decades covered survey data.

title: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
text: seromodel_object. object containing relevant information implementation model. details refer fit_seromodel.

title: Run the specified stan model for the Force-of-Infection and estimates de seroprevalence based on the result of the fit. â€” run_seromodel
code: if (FALSE) { serodata <- prepare_serodata(serodata) run_seromodel (serodata,            seromodel_name = "constant_foi_bi") }
